Name: Human Footprint
Description:
The human footprint in British Columbia was developed using layers associated with human pressures: Urban Areas, Buildings, Population Density, Roads, Railways, Navigable Waterways, Transmission Lines, Seismic Lines, Pipelines, Mining, Dams, Oil and Gas infrastructure, Agriculture, Pastures, Forestry, Recreation Features. To assign a magnitude of human pressure, we use the 0-1 continuum scale, where 1 is the highest intensity of human pressure. Each input was weighted based on the relative score following previous HF studies on global and regional scales.

Value Interpretation:

Values are the result of the sum of the multivariate human pressures in that area.

Reference:

Arias et al. (2022) The human footprint in British Columbia. Unpublished dataset.

Name: Road Density
Description:
The road density in the planning unit pixel using the Digital Road Atlas (DRA) combining the four categories: highways, secondary, tertiary and winter road networks. The data was converted to logarithmic scale.

Value Interpretation:

High values mean more presence of roads in the planning unit

Reference:

Digital Road Atlas (DRA), GeoBC, Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, BC, Canada, aquired date 2021-12, data from the British Columbia Geographic Data (https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca)

Name: Forward Multivariate Climatic Velocity
Description:
Representing velocity of climate change based on climate change projections and slopes, in which species must migrate over the surface to maintain constant climate conditions. Forward velocity provides a measure of the rate at which an organism would need to migrate over the land surface to maintain similar climate conditions, as regional climate conditions change.

Value Interpretation:

Forward climate velocity primarily represents climate-change exposure for species inhabiting the geographic areas considered. High forward climate velocity values may suggest a greater threat of local extirpation of species inhabiting a site due to the rapid migration that would be needed to track changing climate conditions.

Reference:

Carroll, C., J. J. Lawler, D. R. Roberts, and A. Hamann. 2015. Biotic and climatic velocity identify contrasting areas of vulnerability to climate change. PLoS ONE 10:e0140486. ; Hamann, A., D. Roberts, Q. Barber, C. Carroll, and S. Nielsen. 2015. Velocity of climate change algorithms for guiding conservation and management. Global Change Biology 21:997–1004.

Name: Backward Multivariate Climatic Velocity
Description:
Representing velocity of climate change based on climate change projections and slopes, in which species must migrate over the surface to maintain constant climate conditions. Backward (or reverse) velocity utilizes a target location (pixel) of interest and measures the rate at which an organism from similar climate conditions would need to migrate to colonize that target pixel (Cartwright, J. M., 2020).

Value Interpretation:

Backward (reverse) climate velocity primarily represents climate-change implications for the geographic area itself that is being considered. High backward velocity indicates that it might be difficult for species to colonize that site in the future (in response to climate change). Backward velocity provides information for the areas themselves, in terms of the accessibility of those locations to the biotic communities that could potentially inhabit them in the future

Reference:

Carroll, C., J. J. Lawler, D. R. Roberts, and A. Hamann. 2015. Biotic and climatic velocity identify contrasting areas of vulnerability to climate change. PLoS ONE 10:e0140486. ; Hamann, A., D. Roberts, Q. Barber, C. Carroll, and S. Nielsen. 2015. Velocity of climate change algorithms for guiding conservation and management. Global Change Biology 21:997–1004.

Name: Absolute Climatic Dissimilarity
Description:
Climatic dissimilarity is the most fundamental measure of exposure to climate change in that it represents how different will the future climate at a location be from its current climate. Climate dissimilarity in addition to the absolute magnitude of dissimilarity between current and future climates at a location. If the biota in an area was adapted to large interannual climate variations, it might be less sensitive to future climate change. Climate dissimilarity represents a holistic quantitative estimate of the magnitude of change between baseline and future climate (Cartwright, J. M., 2020)

Value Interpretation:

High values for climate dissimilarity represent locations where climate is projected to change dramatically (considering multiple climate variables) whereas low values represent locations with projections of modest climate change. For instance, low climate dissimilarity induces low climate vulnerability areas.

Reference:

Carroll, C. 2018. Climatic dissimilarity data for North America at 1 km resolution. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.1473825. Available online at https://adaptwest.databasin.org/pages/climatic-dissimilarityy

Name: Relative Climatic Dissimilarity
Description:
Relative climatic dissimilarity represents how different will the future climate at a location be from its current climate using climate variables relative to the historical interannual climatic variability. Relative dissimilarity does not show the strong pattern of increasing values at high latitudes that was evident for absolute dissimilarity. Conversely, some areas that now experience low climate variability between years, they will in the future experience relatively low absolute dissimilarity but high relative dissimilarity. Absolute and relative dissimilarity describe different aspects of climate exposure and should be seen as complementary.

Value Interpretation:

High values for climate dissimilarity represent locations where climate is projected to change dramatically relative to the historical interannual climatic variability. For instance, low climate dissimilarity induces low climate vulnerability areas

Reference:

Mahony CR, Cannon AJ, Wang T, Aitken SN (2017) A closer look at novel climates: new methods and insights at continental to landscape scales. Global Change Biology, 23, 3934-3955.
